prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We choose a spectral resolution of 71 KHz, corresponding to a velocity resolution of 0.096 km s$^{-1}$. This high velocity resolution is necessary to detect a subtle change of the velocity within $\sim$1.0 km s$^{-1}$ in the disk, especially if the disk is close to face-on.

Our desired angular resolution is about 0.22" based on the distances (300 pc) of the targets in C18O and 13CO observations which gives a similar linear resolution of ~65 AU scale to what is observed toward L328-IRS in last ALMA cycle 2 observation. This resolution will be enough to characterize disk structures as the case of L328-IRS. In the angular resolution set-up, we intend to obtain 10 arc-sec scale structure in the envelope. This is to obtain the dense gas emission in the envelope and may be critical to determine an accurate mass estimation of the envelope gas.

The required sensitivity is set to successfully investigate the disk with C18O line which is thought to be the best tracer of the disk structure. Based on the L328-IRS observation in last ALMA cycle 2, we assigned the peak flux density of about 70 mJy in a scale of the disk for VeLLOs. We set up 13CO line, as another good disk tracer for the case that C18O line is too weak, which is four times brighter than C18O line. We set our observing sensitivity in C18O to be 6 mJy with which we may detect the accretion disk with S/N~12.

We choose a spectral resolution of 71 KHz, corresponding to a velocity resolution of 0.096 km s$^{-1}$. This high velocity resolution is necessary to detect a subtle change of the velocity within $\sim$1.0 km s$^{-1}$ in the disk, especially if the disk is close to face-on.

Our desired angular resolution is about 0.26" based on the distances (250 pc) of the targets in C18O and 13CO observations which gives a similar linear resolution of ~65 AU scale to what is observed toward L328-IRS in last ALMA cycle 2 observation. This resolution will be enough to characterize disk structures as the case of L328-IRS. In the angular resolution set-up, we intend to obtain 10 arc-sec scale structure in the envelope. This is to obtain the dense gas emission in the envelope and may be critical to determine an accurate mass estimation of the envelope gas.

The required sensitivity is set to successfully investigate the disk with C18O line which is thought to be the best tracer of the disk structure. Based on the L328-IRS observation in last ALMA cycle 2, we assigned the peak flux density of about 70 mJy in a scale of the disk for VeLLOs. We set our observing sensitivity in C18O to be 6 mJy with which we may detect the accretion disk with S/N~12.

Our desired angular resolution is about 0.26" based on the distances (250 pc) of the targets in C18O and 13CO observations which gives a similar linear resolution of ~65 AU scale to what is observed toward L328-IRS in last ALMA cycle 2 observation. This resolution will be enough to characterize disk structures as the case of L328-IRS. In the angular resolution set-up, we intend to obtain 10 arc-sec scale structure in the envelope. This is to obtain the dense gas emission in the envelope and may be critical to determine an accurate mass estimation of the envelope gas.

The required sensitivity is set to successfully investigate the disk with C18O line which is thought to be the best tracer of the disk structure. We choose a spectral resolution of 71 KHz, corresponding to a velocity resolution of 0.096 km s$^{-1}$. This high velocity resolution is necessary to detect a subtle change of the velocity within $\sim$1.0 km s$^{-1}$ in the disk, especially if the disk is close to face-on.

Our desired angular resolution is about 0.43" based on the distances (150 pc) of the targets in C18O and 13CO observations which gives a similar linear resolution of ~65 AU scale to what is observed toward L328-IRS in last ALMA cycle 2 observation. This resolution will be enough to characterize disk structures as the case of L328-IRS. In the angular resolution set-up, we intend to obtain 10 arc-sec scale structure in the envelope. This is to obtain the dense gas emission in the envelope and may be critical to determine an accurate mass estimation of the envelope gas.

The required sensitivity is set to successfully investigate the disk with C18O line which is thought to be the best tracer of the disk structure. Based on the L328-IRS observation in last ALMA cycle 2, we assigned the peak flux density of about 70 mJy in a scale of the disk for VeLLOs. We set our observing sensitivity in C18O to be 6 mJy with which we may detect the accretion disk with S/N~12.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Our recent ALMA cycle 2 data led us to find the first accreting disk in one of the Very Low Luminosity Objects (VeLLOs), L328-IRS, also known as a proto-brown dwarf candidate. It is rotating, but neither in Keplerian nor in angular momentum conserved manner, being different from any disk of low-mass protostars at the stages of Class 0 and I. Which makes the disk so different? In order to answer this question we propose to observe in C18O and 13CO 2-1 four VeLLOs showing CO outflows from single dish observations, at 0.2~0.4 arcsec angular resolutions. Our observations will help to constrain on how the disks of VeLLOs form and help to understand what the VeLLOs are.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Kinematics of an Accretion Disk in a Proto-Brown Dwarf Candidate, L328-IRS, and Its Implication (PI: C. W. Lee)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Radio Astronomy Division, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
